user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
```c
int32 OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData(osal_id_t *task_id, const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_id);

    /* The "sysdata" and "sysdata_size" must be passed to the underlying impl for validation */
    return_code = OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(sysdata, sysdata_size);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl,
                                         (void *)sysdata, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *task_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&token);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    if (sysdata == NULL || sysdata_size != sizeof(pthread_t))
    {
        return OS_INVALID_POINTER;
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No statically unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided code. Rationale:
- The OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_id) macro expands to a BUGCHECK call, but the BUGCHECK implementation is not provided as a non-returning (noreturn) construct here; even if it aborts at runtime for a NULL pointer, that is a runtime condition-dependent abort, not statically unreachable code in the source.
- The early return after OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(...) is conditional on the validation result; both the successful and error paths are reachable depending on input values (sysdata and sysdata_size). This is normal defensive validation, not unreachable code.
- The conditional block that assigns *task_id and calls OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token) is executed only when OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch returns OS_SUCCESS; that return value is determined at runtime, so the block is not statically unreachable.
- Auxiliary functions (OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_ObjectIdFromToken, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl) all contain only conditional flows or straightforward returns; there are no statements following unconditional returns or after constructs known here to be non-returning.

Given the information provided, there are no code fragments that are provably unreachable and thus none to report for further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
